required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Methylsulfonylmethane (MSM) on Cardiometabolic Health
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Methylsulfonylmethane (MSM) on Cardiometabolic Health

brief_summary.textblock: Obesity- related diseases are linked to elevated levels of inflammation, oxidative stress, and metabolic dysfunction. Methylsulfonylmethane (MSM) is a naturally occurring compound that demonstrates antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects. Improvements in measures of metabolic health have been observed in mouse models of obesity and type 2 diabetes following MSM treatment. However, the effect of MSM on obesity-related risk factors for disease in humans has not been investigated. Therefore, the purpose of this investigation will be to determine whether MSM supplementation improves metabolic health, and markers of inflammation and oxidative status.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Double-blind placebo controlled randomized controlled trial

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline blood glucose at 4, 8, and 16 weeks
Change from baseline blood cholesterol at 4, 8, and 16 weeks
Change from baseline blood pressure at 4, 8, and 16 weeks

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline insulin at 4, 8, and 16 weeks
Change from baseline resting metabolic rate at 16 weeks
Change from baseline percent body fat at 4, 8, and 16 weeks
Change from baseline in waist circumference at 4, 8, and 16 weeks
Change from baseline in blood markers of inflammation and oxidative stress at 4, 8, and 16 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Inflammatory markers will include c-reactive protein, interleukin-6, and Tumor necrosis factor-alpha. Oxidative stress will be determined by total antioxidant capacity assay.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in pulmonary function tests
secondary_outcome.description: Pulmonary function tests include forced expiratory volume in 1 second to forced vital capacity ration and slow vital capacity measurement. Expired nitric oxide has also been included as a marker of pulmonary inflammation.

arm_group.description: pill capsules containing white rice flour

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- overweight or obese adults without any diagnosed disease or current medications other than birth control. Participants must agree to maintain diet and physical activity levels throughout study.
Exclusion Criteria:
- normal weight adults, or overweight/obese adults that do not meet the criteria for metabolically unhealthy obesity. Individuals currently on medications, or with diagnosed disease. Pregnant or nursing women, or women planning to become pregnant within the study timeframe. Lack of access to reliable transportation to study site, lack of internet access, or non-english speaking.
